fields.Conference/Meeting Name: International Conference on Finite Fields and Their Applications 2025 (Fq16)
fields.Conference Location: University of São Paulo, São Carlos, SP, Brazil
fields.Sponsoring Organization: Department of Mathematics, Boise State University
fields.Description/Abstract: <p><span>A polynomial </span><span>$h$</span><span> over </span><span>$\mathbb{F}_q$</span><span> is called a </span><span>\emph</span><span>{permutation polynomial} over </span><span>$\mathbb{F}_q$</span><span> if the evaluation map </span><span>$x\mapsto h(x)$</span><span> is a bijection. </span> <span>For a polynomial </span><span>$f$</span><span> over </span><span>$\mathbb{F}_q$</span><span>, the </span><span>\emph</span><span>{permutation resemblance} of </span><span>$f$</span><span>, </span><span>$\pres(f)$</span><span>, is defined by the minimum cardinality of the image set of </span><span>$f-h$</span><span>, where </span><span>$h$</span><span> runs through all permutation polynomials over </span><span>$\mathbb{F}_q$</span><span>. The notion </span><span>$\pres(f)$</span><span> provides a way to determine how far </span><span>$f$</span><span> is from being a permutation polynomial. Furthermore, it was shown in </span><span>\cite</span><span>{prestheory} that </span><span>$\pres(f)$</span><span> has application in constructing permutation polynomials with some good properties in cryptography. More precisely, the </span><span>\emph</span><span>{differential uniformity} of </span><span>$f$</span><span> is defined by the maximum number of solutions in </span><span>$\mathbb{F}_q$</span><span> to the equation </span><span>$f(x a)-f(x)=b$</span><span> where </span><span>$(a,b)$</span><span> run through all elements of </span><span>$\mathbb{F}_q^{*}\times \mathbb{F}_q$</span><span>. An important research problem is to construct permutation polynomials with low differential uniformity. </span> <span>In this talk, we present an integer programming approach to compute </span><span>$\pres(f)$</span><span>, and rephrase the problem of finding a permutation polynomial with the lowest differential uniformity, based on results from </span><span>\cite</span><span>{presalg}. Moreover, we show that we can significantly reduce the problem size of the latter, while compromising the </span><span>optimality</span><span>, by computing the </span><span>$\pres(f)$</span><span> first. </span></p>
